results.title: Lies spies and Olympics
results.creator_credit: Rob McAuley, Film Australia and Peter Butt
results.brief_description: The 1956 Olympic Games held in Melbourne have become etched in Australian mythology as a watershed in our sporting, cultural and civic history. This fascinating documentary examines the era in which they were held, post World War II, and how that influenced both the staging of the Games and some of the extraordinary events which occurred during it (such as the defection of Hungarian athletes). It looks beyond the myth to discover a compelling story of deceit, clashing egos and local and international politics which almost turned the so-called ‘Friendly Games’ into a national disaster.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob McAuley, Film Australia and Peter Butt

results.title: Lies [Widescreen] (E)
results.creator_credit: Chul Shin, Shincine Communications, Korea Pictures and Jang Sun-Woo
results.brief_description: Jang Sun-Woo’s Lies (based on a notorious Korean novel, whose author Jang Jung Il was sentenced to six months jail over its content) takes the very simple premise of a sexual affair between an older man and a younger woman and turns it on its head. Right from its opening scenes where the ‘actors’ discuss their roles and the difficulties of performing on-screen sex, the audience is led into deep analysis of what film authenticity means. This becomes a tantalizing proposition as the affair between J (Lee Sang Hyun), 38-year-old married man and the innocent Y (Kim Tae Yeon), an 18-year-old student determined to lose her virginity, becomes a sadomasochistic one. As these two people explore just how far the other is willing to go, we as an audience are asking the same question of the film as each erotic act becomes seemingly more real. Sun-Woo heightens this by adopting a documentary verite style that distances itself from its main protagonists. Finally the blurred boundaries between what is performance and what isn’t ultimately begs the question, ‘does the camera lie?’. In Korean with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chul Shin, Shincine Communications, Korea Pictures and Jang Sun-Woo

results.title: Liebelei
results.brief_description: Vienna, 1910; a whirlwind love affair between Fritz, a young lieutenant in the Austro-Hungarian Army, and Christine, the shy and sensitive daughter of a musician, ends in tragedy. Ophuls freely adapted Schnitzler’s play in which Christine’s great love is just another affair for the dissolute lieutenant already involved with a baroness. In the film Fritz’s affair with the baroness has more or less ended and the couple’s expression of undying love (not entirely cynical on his part), is threatened by the baron’s vengefulness - the portrayal, in the play, of innocence destroyed by cynical players in a decadent society gives way to Ophuls’ atmospheric portrayal of love doomed by hollow class distinction and hidebound notions of honour. Cast includes Magda Schneider, Wolfgang Liebeneiner and Gustaf Grundgens. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Lie of the land
results.creator_credit: Anne Whitehead, Barry Pierce and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Maps and Map Reading”.
Using the example of a company setting up a VHF radio network in rugged mountain country, the film examines the lines of sight, gradients and contour patterns. Produced for the State Emergency Service Tasmania.

results.title: Lickety-split licorice
results.creator_credit: Joe Hayward, Moreland-Latchford Productions, Sterling Educational Films and Jan Steen
results.brief_description: A boy and girl making liquorice, stretch it outside in a tangled web which leads to utter chaos as people become entangled in it. When someone snips the gigantic piece of liquorice, the scenes flash rapidly backwards to reality. No spoken commentary - English intertitles.

results.title: Lichtenstein in London
results.brief_description: In February 1968, an exhibition of the paintings of the American pop artist Roy Liechtenstein was held at the Tate Gallery in London. This is a film record of the exhibition and both members of the public and Liechtenstein comment on the work displayed. The public were interviewed by Hugh Evans. Roy Liechtenstein’s comments were taken from interviews by Alan Soloman recorded for National Education Television and by David Sylvester recorded for British Broadcasting Corporation.
